column1: #This mapping was created following and expanding upon the SSSOM guidance: https://mapping-commons.github.io/sssom/spec/

column16: syntax_comment

The DwC term expects a verbatim input (so anything really), whereas MIxS expects decimal degrees input as {float} {float}. Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.
The DwC term expects decimal degrees, and so does MIxS - however, the DwC term expects one value, while MIxS expects two
The DwC term expects decimal degrees, and so does MIxS - however, the DwC term expects one value, while MIxS expects two

MIxS expects two input values in decimal degrees, while DwC only expects one as verbatim (so anything really). Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

MIxS expects two input values in decimal degrees, while DwC only expects one as verbatim (so anything really). Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

The DwC term expects a verbatim input (so anything really), while MIxS expects a {float} {unit} entry in meters. Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

column2: Minimum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: The example offered by DwC does not include the unit 'meter' as part of the entry in the field, whereas the MIxS syntax would expect the unit to be added. The numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column2: Maximum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: The example offered by DwC does not include the unit 'meter' as part of the entry in the field, whereas the MIxS syntax would expect the unit to be added. The numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column2: Minimum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields. However, this mapping is only based on the definition and term label (DwC example is not consistent).

column2: Maximum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column16: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields. However, this mapping is only based on the definition and term label (DwC example is not consistent).

The DwC term expects verbatim input (so anything really), whereas MIxS expects {float} {unit} in meter. Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

The DwC example only expects one country name, while MIxS expects two identifications of location (country or sea name + specific region name). Additionally MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would be a termLabel[termID] combination. Despite these differences, one could interchangeably use these fields to hunt for the syntactic signature of country names (i.e. words delimited by a special character or whitespace) with a tagging or NLP routine, thus suggesting this to be a closeMatch. This closeness is only on country names (thus limited to the DwC -> MIxS direction of the mapping).

The DwC example only expects one sea identifier, while MIxS expects an additional region identifier (country or sea name + specific region name). Additionally, MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would be a termLabel[termID] combination. Despite these differences, one could interchangeably use these fields to hunt for the syntactic signature of sea names (i.e. words delimited by a special character or whitespace) with a tagging or NLP routine, thus suggesting this to be a closeMatch. This closeness is only on sea names (thus limited to the DwC -> MIxS direction of the mapping).

Both are string lists with some special characters that need not overlap. As noted [in this rubric](https://github.com/tdwg/gbwg/pull/78/files#r846255765), this qualifies the terms as relatedMatch.  DwC expects a list (of undefined length) of values separated by a vertical bar space  '|', while MIxS expects two words (country or sea name + specific region name). Additionally MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would not only be a word but a termLabel[termID] combination

DwC requests compliance with ISO 8601-1:2019, so does MIxS. Note, however, that this is only a recommendation in both cases. Thus, non ISO entries may be allowed. Stricter recommendations from both standards bodies would support this mapping.
Both expect PIDs of a sort (undefined and unrestricted as to what kind - a mix of letters, numbers, etc.). The mapping as exactMatch is further supported by the MIxS key referencing the DwC key.

Both fields accept numbers, letters, and special characters. DwC expects a list of terms and corresponding identifiers, linked with colons and both in quotation marks (quoted strings). The MIxS term expects a string (which could also include special characters and numbers - ref candidate phyla names).

DwC expects the name of, reference to, or description (which could also include a URI, IRI, etc.), while MIxS expects free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax. The DwC description may actively call for higher diversity of strings, the MIxS term is too loosely defined to narrow down the expected diversity of stings either. Following the same logic as with the dwC:verbatim fields, we are using relatedMatch to map the two terms to one another.

DwC expects the name of, reference to, or description (which could also include a URI, IRI, etc.), while MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would not only be a word but a termLabel[termID] combination
MIxS expects {float} {unit}, while DwC only expects {float}
MIxS expects {float} {unit}, while DwC only expects {unit}
The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.
The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.
The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.
The DwC term expects a link as well as text about the type of association, whereas MIxS only expects a URL.
The DwC would expect a comma separated list of citations, URIs, etc., thus accepting non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.
The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.
The DwC term would expect a list of IDs (could be links) or names, while MIxS expects URLs only.
